review.title: Bound Your Models! How to Make OWL an ASP Modeling Language
review.abstract: To exploit the Web Ontology Language OWL as an answer set programming (ASP) language, we introduce the notion of bounded model semantics, as an intuitive and computationally advantageous alternative to its classical semantics. We show that a translation into ASP allows for solving a wide range of bounded-model reasoning tasks, including satisfiability and axiom entailment but also novel ones such as model extraction and enumeration. Ultimately, our work facilitates harnessing advanced semantic web modeling environments for the logic programming community through an "off-label use" of OWL.
histories: International Workshop on User-Oriented Logic Programming (IULP 2015), co-located with the 31st International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP 2015), Proceedings of the International Workshop on User-Oriented Logic Programming (IULP 2015), Editors: Stefan Ellmauthaler and Claudia Schulz, pages 33-49, August 2015

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In ASP, knowledge is encoded in a set of logical rules and interpreted within the stable model of semantics [8,9]. Recent developments have led to powerful systems such as dlv [17] and gringo / clasp [6], to name a few, capable of solving a wide variety of problems [7]. In particular, ASP has shown that it is well suited for large combinatorial search problems, as dedicated solvers have been specifically designed to render all solutions [2]. However, it has often been pointed out that while it is a powerful and versatile form of formalism, popularity and widespread adoption of logical programming in general and answer-set programming in particular is hampered by the unavailability of user-friendly and scalable editing environments. On the other hand, formalisms that come with a more elaborate modeling of tools - especially language - are hampered.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section we provide the necessary background for description logic and response set programming.

sections.heading: 2.1 Description Logics
sections.text: OWL 2 DL, the version of the Web Ontology Language on which we focus, is finally defined on the basis of the Description Logic (DLs, [3,25]).We briefly summarize the Description Logic SROIQ (see [13] for details).Let NI, NC, and NR be finite, with A being a SROIQ ABox, T a SROIQTBox, and R a SROIQ RBox. Table 2 shows the respective axiom types available in the three parts, and we refer to each TBox axiom as a General Concept Integration (GCI).The original definition of SROIQ contained more RBox axioms (expressing transitivity, (a) symmetry, (ir).We will refer to each TBox axiom as a General Concept Integration (GCI), with the SROIQ inclusion (not the GCI and GIQ inclusion) being decisive.

sections.heading: 2.2 Answer-Set Programming
sections.text: We give a brief overview of the syntax and semantics of disjunctive logic programs under the Answer Sets semantics [9]. We fix a countable set of U of (domain) elements, also called constants; and assume that a total order < over the domain elements. An atom is an expression p (t1,., tn), where p is a predicate of nature n (0) and each ti is either a variable or an element of U. An atom is grounded when it is free of variables. BU denotes the set of all basic atoms over U. A (disjunctive) rule is of the forma1 rule · · · a variable or an element of U.., bk, not bm, not bm, with n ².

sections.heading: 3 Bounded Models
sections.text: If we argue in the logic of description, we can assume arbitrary cardinality. However, in many fields of application, the sphere of interest is limited to models of finite domain size (referred to as finite model thinking, a natural assumption in database theory), but has recently come under intense study (18,5,24). Contrary to the assumption that the domain is limited (but of arbitrary, unknown size), we consider the case where the domain has a priority known cardinality, more precisely when the domain coincides with the individuals mentioned in the knowledge base. We refer to such models as limited models and argue that this modification of standard DL semantics represents a more intuitive definition of what is considered and expected to be a model of some knowledge bases. 1Definition 1 (Bounded-Model Semantics). Let K be a SROIQ knowledge base.

sections.heading: 3.1 Extraction & Enumeration of Bounded Models
sections.text: When performing satisfaction tests in DLs (the primary reasoning task considered there), a model constructed by a rational person serves only as a witness to the assertion of satisfaction and not as an accessible artifact. However, as mentioned above, our approach aims at scenarios in which a knowledge base is a formal description of a problem for which each model is a solution. Then, retrieving one, several, or all models is a natural task, as opposed to merely verifying their existence. By model extraction, we designate the task of materializing an identified model in order to work with it, i.e. to fully inspect it and reuse it in downstream processes. The natural continuation of model extraction is to make all models explicit by performing model transformations.

sections.heading: 3.2 Complexity of Bounded Model Reasoning
sections.text: The combined complexity of decision-making in SROIQ about extending all elements of the C system and extending the C element is only part of the problem we are able to prove in practice when we engage in a drastic reduction in complexity in the world. Furthermore, we leave R all role expressions and role chains (including subchains) in K. Obviously, C and R are of polynomial size.

This construction is easily encoded by the following rules: B (K): = {A (X): − not A (X), (X) | A (K), B (1) {¬ A (X): − not A (X), (X) | A (K).

sections.heading: 4.2 Axiom Encoding
sections.text: In the next step, we will turn each axiom-A-R-T into a constraint that will ultimately exclude all possible interpretations that are not satisfactory. Furthermore, each individual assertion in ABox A will further restrict the search space, since for some present fact A (a) eliminates any prospective solution that includes a (a). sections.heading: 5 Evaluation
sections.text: We have implemented our approach as an open source tool called Wolpertinger.2 The logic programs obtained can be evaluated with most modern ASP solvers, but the evaluation was done with Clingo [6] for grounding and solving, as it is currently the most prominent solver leading the recent contests [2]. We present preliminary evaluation results based on simple ontologies encoding constraint-satisfaction-like combinatorial problems. Existing OWL ontologies typically used for benchmarking, such as SNOMED or GALEN [29.23], do not fit our purpose, as they are modelled on classical semantics and often contain little or no ABox information.Our tests provide runtimes for Wolpertinger and the popular HermiT rationist [10]. While a direct comparison would not be fair, the tests carried out are merely intended to demonstrate the feasibility of our approach and the unfeasibility of the DL axiatization.

sections.heading: 5.1 Unsatisfiability
sections.text: We construct an unsatisfactory knowledge base Kn = (An, T n, ∅), with Tn and An as follows: T n = {A1 r.A2,..., An r.An + 1} (13) {Ai Aj 1 ≤ i < j ≤ n + 1} (14) An = {A1 (a1), (a1),.., (an) (15) Inspired by frequent drawer problems, we forced Kn an r-chain of length n + 1 without repeating elements, but only n individuals such as a2 https: / / github.com / wolpertinger-reasoner 3 Unix operating system, 1.8 Ghz Intel Core i7 processor, 4GB of memory. Both tools run with standard Java VM settings.

sections.heading: 5.2 Model Extraction and Model Enumeration
sections.text: For this purpose, we created a knowledge base in which Sudokus with 108 named persons, 13 concept names and 1 role name were fully and correctly modeled. When calling a satisfaction check of this knowledge base with HermiT, no answer was given within 15 minutes. On average, Wolpertinger delivers a solution for a particular Sudoku instance in about 6 seconds, of which more than 5 seconds is needed for grounding, while the actual solution takes less than 0.1 seconds. We used the knowledge base for the model enumeration, but removed information about pre-filled cells, generating new Sudoku instances from the task. The size of the generated program is 13 MB, the grounding process takes about 6 seconds, which is reflected in Table 6.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: With this paper we have the starting point for further developments on the theoretical and practical side, as well as we can identify the benefits for both the description logic and logic programming community. For the latter, our approach allows to use OWL as an ASP modeling language and therefore make use of the available tool support. Although the modeling capabilities are limited, we argue that quite large and involved problem scenarios can be modeled in OWL ontologies. Obviously, evaluations of our system remain mandatory in relation to such ontologies. Complementary, modeling extraction and enumeration complement DL reasoning tasks for which our ASP translation not only represents a feasible approach, but also appears to be an application of ASP in another field of research. In addition, the framework can be expanded to realize non-standard reasoning tasks that are useful for debugging purposes such as axiom determination, explanation, justification and induction, the use of the model as well as prominence capabilities.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We are grateful for the valuable feedback from our colleagues and anonymous workshop experts, who have helped to improve this work significantly.

On the other side, formalisms coming with a more elaborate modeling tool support – most notably the Web Ontology Language OWL [31] – are often preferred, even if the application scenario actually is of a constraint-satisfaction type which does not go well with OWL’s standard semantics allowing for models of arbitrary size.

While reasoning in OWL under the classical semantics is N2ExpTime-complete [15], we show that reasoning under the bounded model semantics is merely NP-complete.

Therefore, we propose a different approach and definine a translation of SROIQ knowledge bases (the logical counterparts to OWL ontologies) into answer set programs [4], such that the set of bounded models coincides with the set of answer sets of the obtained program, allowing us to use existing answer set solvers (see [2] for an overview) for bounded model reasoning.

A major such extension is considering the reasoning task of answering queries, most prominently (unions of) conjunctive queries, positive queries, conjunctive 2-way regular path queries, and monadically defined queries subsuming all of the former [27].

It is not overly difficult to show that answering all these query types over SROIQ knowledge bases (and hence over OWL ontologies) under the bounded model semantics is Π P -complete, which again contrasts with the much worse results (if any) for the unbounded case [26,11].

metadata.abstractText: To exploit the Web Ontology Language OWL as an answer set programming (ASP) language, we introduce the notion of bounded model semantics, as an intuitive and computationally advantageous alternative to its classical semantics. We show that a translation into ASP allows for solving a wide range of bounded-model reasoning tasks, including satisfiability and axiom entailment but also novel ones such as model extraction and enumeration. Ultimately, our work facilitates harnessing advanced semantic web modeling environments for the logic programming community through an “off-label use” of OWL.
